bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 6, 1944

div1.p: Kean discusses Finlay's mosquito theory and Reed's experimentation. He comments on a planned mural depicting the story of yellow fever in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, December 6, 1944

opener.dateline:
2804 N St. u. w.
Washington 7, D C
Dec. 6/44

div1.p:
I was about to begin a letter to you
yesterday where the mail came with
your good letter and inclosing yours to
Gen. Truby of Dec. 1st- Various things inter-
vewed to stop me until this morning, which
was just as well as I have been able
to think over and look up several matters.
What I had on my mind was a letter from
Truby inclosing back to me, one from Dr-
A. Diaz Albertini to him, mailed in my
care, at the suggestion of our friend Dr
Domingo Ramos, as neither of them knew
Truby's address- There was also in it a note
from Dr. Ramos to me- The subject of the
correspondence was as follows:
Dr. Albertini is the only surviving member
of the Havana Board of Yellow Fever experts
which confirmed the diagnoses of Reed's
cases of experimental yellow fever at Camp
Lazear- He has read in Truby's book, Reed's
letter to Truby of Dec. 10, 1900. In this he tells
the good news of his first experimental case
which was fully controlled (Kissinger), in which
Reed said “The case is a beautiful one, and
will be seen by the Board of Havana experts
Today, all of whom except Finlay consider the
theory a wild one”- On that board was the noted
2-
Surgeon General William C. Gorgas"--page 158.
He takes exception to Major Reed's statement
and as the only living members of the Com-
mission expresses “my nonconformity with
such an assertion, not only in that which
refers to me, but also to my fellow workers
no longer living: Drs Major Gorgas and
Juan Guiteras”- He calls upon Gen Truby to
publish his letter “in some scientific magazine
of your great country”. Truby is troubled and
worried at this demand and has sent it
all to me to handle- He has written to
Dr. Albertini stating that he has done so
as he is ill and not able to discuss the
matter- I have written a rather long and wordy
letter to Dr. Ramos in which I try to point
out the unreasonable nature of this requests-
I have done this as politely as I can because
I have a sincerely regard for Dr. Albertini-
In the first place if Dr. Albertini is willing
to assert that he was a convert to the Finlay
theory before he had seen even the first one
of Reed's Camp Lazear cases, I do not see how
we can dispute his memory, though I am
quite surprised at it. It has always been my
1.
understanding that before the Camp Lazear demon
stration Dr. Finlay's faithful follower and disciple
Dr. C. Delgado was his ‘sole disciple’- And Dr. Carlos E. Finlay his
son (whose recent death I have been sorry to learn)
so states in his book Carlos Finlay and Yellow Fever
Chap V pp. 94 and 95. 2 As to Gorgas he has put on
3
July 12 1902
record in his Final Official Report to Gen. Wood
with admirable frankness, his disbelief at that time in the mosquito
theory being the only or even the usual way of its
transmission- This is also stated in Dr. Carlos E.
Finlays book p. 119- And Gorgas said this to me
in practically the same words when I asked him
to back up Reed's paper at the Pan American
Medical Congress in Havana Feb 4 1901- He would
not state his adhesion to the Finlay theory after
all the evidence was in- It was his own
work which finally convinced him-
So we have left only Dr. Juan Guiteras
unaccounted for- It is my belief that he was
convinced by the Camp Lazear experiments.
Dr. Guiteras said of Finlay's epedemeological
work in the long period before 1900: “If he fail-
ed to convince us, the fault was ours and not
of his prevision” This does not sound like the
language of a convinced disciple-

I cannot see that Gen. Truby is called
upon to justify a statement by made by
Major Reed which was certainly a matter
of common belief at the time he made it,
although after the Commission on Board saw
Kissinger's case Dr. Guiteras may have become
a convert- It is evident that Dr. Albertini
has erred in his letter as to Gen. Gorgas. If
he or Dr. Ramos has any evidence as to the
data of Dr. Guiteras's conversion Dr. Albertini
or Dr. Ramos might publish it if they think
it desirable- To me it does not seem that
it is at all to their discredit to have shared the
common belief of the medical profession until con-
Ac
k
4
vincing proof of the to them new theory was
laid before them- If Gen. Truby I think agrees
with me that if the Director of the Instituto Finlay
can find every documentary evidence of the accep-
tance by Dr. Guiteras of the Finlay theory before Dec. 10-
1900 it should be presented to you who are the person
in the world most familiar with the details of the
Yellow Fever Episode of 1900-1901- Then you and Dr
Ramos can consider what form the letter should
take and how it should be published- I hope
that you may be willing to accept this judicial posi-
tion- Personally I do not think a case can be made
out. Also I admire Gen. Truby's book too much to
appear to criticise anything in it, especially I do not
see that any one's reputation is involved in the matter

I am so pleased to know that you saw
Sña Raquel Romero and discussed her plan
of the mural with her- I was uneasy about the
prominence of the female figure which is intended
to bring together the two incidents which tell the
story- This figure was much more prominent
in the sketch which I saw and as I told her
was more suggestive of Hollywood than of
the Muse of History- As regards the use of
the caduceus I told her that in my opinion
it has no medical connotation whatever-
It was selected by the U. S. Medical Dept.
because it was used by heralds to secure
immunity from attack in war, and it
signifies medical immunity under the
Geneva treaties- I am returning your
article on Moran at Rochester- It had
apprently been handled a little roughly and
one small piece is torn out. I have patched
it up as well as I could-

SNA = Senorita
I am much pleased to get the snapshots of Sna
div1.closer: Cordially yours J. R. K. I will send a P. S. tomorrow in answer to your letter.
